citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The licensee did not submit a written itinerary for events involving overnight stays at least two days prior to travel. The
facility emailed the Animal Care Field Office a copy of their itinerary on September 2nd, 2024. However, the itinerary
outlined travel taking place the day before on September 1st, 2024. Additionally, the itinerary did not include all locations
where the animals would be exhibited or temporarily housed during the travel dates of September 2nd – September 7th.
Itineraries enable effective tracking of animal movement, biosecurity monitoring, and permit inspections to be conducted
in accordance with the AWA when animals are away from the home site.
Traveling exhibitors who intend to exhibit any animal at any location other than the facility’s approved site (including, but
not limited to, circuses, traveling educational exhibits, animal acts, and petting zoos), except for travel that does not
extend overnight, shall submit a written itinerary to the AC Deputy Administrator no fewer than 2 days in advance of travel
containing all complete and accurate information as outlined in this subpart.
Correct by September 11, 2024.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport nonhuman primates.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, neither primary enclosure housing the two capuchins had the words "Live Animals" or “Wild
Animals” on the top or sides in letters at least one inch in height, as required. Additionally, there were no arrows to denote
the upright position of the crate during transport.
Failure to properly label crates used to transfer live animals could result in injury to the animals, along with mishandling
during transportation.
Unless the enclosure is permanently affixed to the conveyance, it should be clearly marked on top and on one or more
sides with the words “Live Animals” or “Wild Animals” in letters at least 1 inch (2.5 cm.) high, and with arrows or other
markings to indicate the correct upright position of the primary enclosure, in order to help ensure proper handling while in
transport.
Correct by September 11, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.126(c) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
The licensee did not submit a written itinerary for events involving overnight stays at least two days prior to travel. The 
facility emailed the Animal Care Field Office a copy of their itinerary on September 2nd, 2024. However, the itinerary 
outlined travel taking place the day before on September 1st, 2024. Additionally, the itinerary did not include all locations 
where the animals would be exhibited or temporarily housed during the travel dates of September 2nd – September 7th.  
Itineraries enable effective tracking of animal movement, biosecurity monitoring, and permit inspections to be conducted 
in accordance with the AWA when animals are away from the home site. 
 
Traveling exhibitors who intend to exhibit any animal at any location other than the facility’s approved site (including, but 
not limited to, circuses, traveling educational exhibits, animal acts, and petting zoos), except for travel that does not 
extend overnight, shall submit a written itinerary to the AC Deputy Administrator no fewer than 2 days in advance of travel 
containing all complete and accurate information as outlined in this subpart. 
Correct by September 11, 2024. 
3.87(f) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport nonhuman primates. 
At the time of inspection, neither primary enclosure housing the two capuchins had the words "Live Animals" or “Wild 
Animals” on the top or sides in letters at least one inch in height, as required. Additionally, there were no arrows to denote 
the upright position of the crate during transport.  
Failure to properly label crates used to transfer live animals could result in injury to the animals, along with mishandling 
during transportation. 
 
Unless the enclosure is permanently affixed to the conveyance, it should be clearly marked on top and on one or more 
sides with the words “Live Animals” or “Wild Animals” in letters at least 1 inch (2.5 cm.) high, and with arrows or other 
markings to indicate the correct upright position of the primary enclosure, in order to help ensure proper handling while in 
transport. 
Correct by September 11, 2024.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
